German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German vriunt, from Old High German friunt, from Proto-Germanic *frijÅndz (â€œlover, friendâ€), from a derivative of Proto-Indo-European *prÄ“y-, *prÄy- (â€œto like, loveâ€). Compare Luxembourgish FrÃ«nd, Dutch vriend, Low German FrÃ¼nd, West Frisian freon, English friend, Danish frÃ¦nde, Swedish frÃ¤nde, Norwegian frende, Faroese frÃ¦ndi, Icelandic frÃ¦ndi, Gothic ğ†ğ‚ğŒ¹ğŒ¾ğ‰ğŒ½ğŒ³ğƒ (frijÅnds).

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /frÉ”ÊÌ¯nt/, [fÊÉ”ÊÌ¯nt]
  • audio (Austria)
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

Freund m (genitive Freundes or Freunds, plural Freunde, female Freundin)

  1. friend
    Lass uns Freunde bleiben.
    Letâ€™s stay friends.
  2. boyfriend
    Hast du einen Freund?
    Do you have a boyfriend?
  3. (obsolete) blood relative (in the sense of a person that is or should be oneâ€™s friend by nature)

Usage notes[edit]

  • Freund (and Freundin) may refer to either a platonic friend or a romantic partner. When used in the singular with a possessive (mein Freund, ihr Freund, etc.), the word usually has a romantic implication, unless the context suggests otherwise.
  • Most derived terms, such as befreundet or Freundschaft, are restricted to the platonic sense, however.
